unnormalised: Okay, so I was really struggling with Differential Calculus back in my 1st year Engg. at IIT Delhi. Seriously, I thought I was gonna fail the Prof. Sharma's course. I'd breezed through maths in school, getting 98/100 in my 12th boards, but this was a whole different ballgame.
normalised: Okay, so I was really struggling with Differential Calculus back in my first year Engineering at I-I-T Delhi. Seriously, I thought I was going to fail the Professor Sharma's course. I'd breezed through maths in school, getting ninety eight divided by one hundred in my twelfth boards, but this was a whole different ballgame.

unnormalised: It wasn’t just the formulas; it was the concepts. Things like limits, derivatives, and integrals – they just wouldn't stick. I remember one particular problem where we had to find the derivative of some crazy function using the chain rule. It looked like something straight out of a sci-fi movie, with exponents and nested functions everywhere.

unnormalised: I tried everything. I read the textbook, solved extra problems from RD Sharma, even asked my senior, Vivek, for help (he was a maths whiz). Nothing seemed to work. I was spending hours trying to understand the basics, but it felt like I was just hitting my head against a wall. My internals were a disaster – like 45/100 in one quiz.

unnormalised: Then, one day, while I was procrastinating by watching a Bollywood movie (totally not recommended before exams!), I had a sort of epiphany. The hero, playing a struggling student, used a real-world analogy to understand a complex concept. It got me thinking. Maybe I was approaching calculus all wrong.

unnormalised: Instead of just memorizing formulas, I started visualizing what was actually happening. For example, I imagined the derivative as the slope of a tangent line to a curve – like the speed of an auto-rickshaw changing as it navigates the chaotic Delhi streets. The integral became the area under the curve – like calculating the total rainfall during the monsoon season using data from 10 rain gauges.

unnormalised: Suddenly, the formulas started to make sense. I started seeing the connections between different concepts. I even started enjoying the challenge of solving difficult problems. My grades started to improve too. I managed to score 75/100 in the final exam, which was a huge relief.

My grades started to improve too. I managed to score seventy five divided by one hundred in the final exam, which was a huge relief.

unnormalised: What really helped me was finding relatable examples. Like, understanding related rates problems by thinking about how quickly the water level rises in Amma's cylindrical cooking pot as she adds water. Or visualizing optimization problems by imagining how a shopkeeper maximizes profit by finding the perfect balance between price and sales.

unnormalised: Differential Calculus is tough, no doubt. But with the right approach and a little bit of Indian context, it can become a lot more understandable, and even fun. Don’t just memorize; visualize, connect, and find real-world examples that resonate with you. You might just surprise yourself.
